did.unittitle: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia Exhibits Department records

bioghist.p: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia was founded in 1812 "for the encouragement and cultivation of the sciences, and the advancement of useful learning." Its collections, acquired through expeditions, gifts, purchases, and exchanges, contain over 17,000,000 specimens. The Academy opened its doors to the public in 1828, growing so rapidly that it outgrew its building three times in sixty years. In 1876, its present home was built at 19th and Benjamin Franklin Parkway, where its permanent exhibits include Dinosaur Hall, and more than 35 dioramas presenting wildlife from Africa, Asia and North America. The Academy also presents changing exhibits and online exhibits.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records related to exhibits at the Academy of Natural Sciences. The records consists primarily of the working files of members of the Exhibits department, including Sean Duran, Harold T. Green, Hollister Knowlton, and Keith Russell. Materials include: correspondence; minutes; proposals; bids and contracts; schedules and staff time sheets; floor plans; sketches of exhibit spaces, subjects, and backgrounds; panel text; specimen acquisition and loan information; photos, negatives, and slides of construction of exhibits, of finished exhibits, and of living animals in their habitats; subject files on materials, artists, other natural history exhibitions. Much the material in this collection relates to the remodeling of Dinosaur Hall and the Discovering Dinosaurs exhibit. The collection also includes: surveys and assessments of the Academy's dioramas and of natural history museums (1936 and 2001); plans and rolled blueprints for construction of Earth Sciences exhibit 1990-1991; photos from the Earth Science Hall (pre-1975); records and photos relating to the fulgerite specimen that had once been on display (now damaged); materials relating to the Deinonyclus sculpture in front of the Academy; brass wall plaques and exhibit signs and labels; field photos; and drawings of specimens and exhibits. Among the Harold T. Green papers, there is a significant amount of documentation of various expeditions, including the Carpenter African expedition of 1955, and the Carpenter Arabian expedition of 1953, the Vanderbilt Africa expedition of 1930, and others. These materials include photographs, equipment lists, bills and receipts,correspondence, and bullets retrieved from specimens. There are also several artifacts that probably belonged to Green, including a pipe and ashtray and a ceramic box.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia: Habitat Groups records (collections 717, 718, 719), ANSP. Exhibits papers (collection 256) and Robert Peck papers.
